summary: This document appears to be a collection of personal, anguished writings and notes, possibly from a victim or associate of Jeffrey Epstein. The text references a miscarriage, forced pregnancy, emotional abuse, and mentions Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell. It includes poetic passages, expressions of despair, and references to New York City.

persons.name: Jeffrey
persons.context: Addressed directly in a message about a miscarriage and pregnancy, and referenced as the father in a context suggesting coercion and control.

persons.name: Ghislaine
persons.context: Mentioned in a desperate query about her whereabouts, suggesting she was expected to be present or involved in the situation.

persons.name: Leon
persons.context: Mentioned in a passing reference to blood no longer being in New York City, context is unclear.

connections.description: Both are mentioned in the same distressed context by the writer, who questions Ghislaine's whereabouts while addressing Jeffrey.

events.title: Miscarriage Incident
events.description: The writer describes flushing a tiny fetus after a miscarriage, blaming Jeffrey for the physical and emotional trauma.

events.title: Ongoing Pregnancy and Ultrasound
events.description: The writer references an upcoming halfway ultrasound for a pregnancy attributed to Jeffrey, expressing fear that the child will be taken and exhaustion from the situation.

events.title: Previous Child Taken
events.description: The writer alludes to a first baby who survived being taken, contributing to their feeling of being a mere vessel.

events.title: National Geographic Reference
events.description: A clipped article from National Geographic June 2004 about New York City is included in the document.

keyFacts: The document contains a first-person account of a miscarriage allegedly resulting from Jeffrey Epstein's actions, with the writer expressing profound trauma and hatred.
It references a current, ongoing pregnancy attributed to Jeffrey Epstein, with the writer expressing fear, exhaustion, and a lack of autonomy.
The writer questions the whereabouts of Ghislaine Maxwell, suggesting her expected involvement or knowledge of the situation.
The text includes intense expressions of guilt and self-loathing, with the writer calling themselves a 'monster' for failing to console another person whose screams haunt them.
The document is a fragmented collection of personal notes, poetry, and clippings, indicating a state of deep psychological distress.
